G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 19A.proposition: This is a civil action for negligence seeking damages in an amount within the jurisdictional limits of the Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A.

G.L. c. 212.proposition: This Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212 and G.L. c. 218, because Plaintiff seeks monetary damages for personal injuries arising from tortious conduct occurring within Massachusetts and within the monetary jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 218.proposition: This Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212 and G.L. c. 218, because Plaintiff seeks monetary damages for personal injuries arising from tortious conduct occurring within Massachusetts and within the monetary jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2, 8 & 9.proposition: Venue is proper in the Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 2, 8 & 9, because the cause of action arose in Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and the Defendant regularly conducts business at the Store in Lowell, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors with respect to the condition of the Premises. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 (1973) (abolishing distinction between invitees and licensees and recognizing a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B\u20136C.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks statutory interest on any judgment pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B–6C, and costs as allowed by law.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors with respect to the condition of the Premises. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 (1973) (abolishing distinction between invitees and licensees and recognizing a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the seminal Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing a unified duty of reasonable care owed by property owners/occupiers to all lawful visitors. The quoted passage is only Kaplan, J.’s concurrence and focuses on trespassers, but the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 707–08 clearly adopts the rule described in the proposition. Thus, the case, as a whole, supports the stated proposition, even though the excerpt itself does not restate it.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: “We hold, therefore, that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. In so doing, we abolish the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees as determinants of the landowner’s duty of care… Henceforth, the standard to be applied is whether in the management of his property the landowner has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others.”

Dubuque v. Cumberland Farms, Inc., 93 Ma.raw_text: Dubuque v. Cumberland Farms, Inc., 93 Mass. App. Ct. 332, 335–36 (2018)
Dubuque v. Cumberland Farms, Inc., 93 Ma.proposition: As the owner, operator, or person in control of the Store, Defendant owed Plaintiff a nondelegable duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the Premises, including shelves and merchandise displays, in a reasonably safe condition, and to protect her from foreseeable risks of harm. See Dubuque v. Cumberland Farms, Inc., 93 Mass. App. Ct. 332, 335–36 (2018).
Dubuque v. Cumberland Farms, Inc., 93 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a store owner’s nondelegable duty to keep the premises—including shelves and merchandise displays—in a reasonably safe condition. Dubuque involves a convenience store’s duty regarding protection from out-of-control vehicles in the parking lot and at the store façade, not interior conditions like shelves or merchandise displays. While the opinion does affirm that a business in possession of real estate open to the public owes invitees a duty of reasonable care to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition, it does not speak in terms of a nondelegable duty or address shelves/merchandise displays, so the citation overstates what the case supports.
Dubuque v. Cumberland Farms, Inc., 93 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Cumberland Farms was ‘in possession of real estate open to the public for business purposes. It owed a duty to a paying patron to use reasonable care to prevent injury to [her] by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional.’ Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 452, 245 N.E.2d 420 (1969) (Carey). ‘As to any invitee [the store] owed the duty of ordinary care and diligence to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition.... What constitutes the required care and diligence is a question of fact.’” Dubuque, 93 Mass. App. Ct. at 349.

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 782–84 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.proposition: Defendant also had a duty to conduct reasonable inspections of shelving and merchandise displays and to correct or warn of dangerous conditions that it knew or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known existed. See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 782–84 (2007).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses a store’s duty in premises liability terms, but it does so in the context of foreign substances on the floor in a self‑service grocery setting and the mode‑of‑operation doctrine. It does not specifically speak to shelving or merchandise displays, nor does it expressly articulate a separate duty to inspect shelving and displays; its focus is on floor hazards (e.g., produce debris) and the notice standard. Thus, using this case to support a specific duty to conduct reasonable inspections of shelving and merchandise displays overstates what the opinion actually holds.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: In particular, as is the case here, fruit and vegetable debris presents an obvious risk of injury to a customer, and a reasonably prudent person would not place these items in an aisle or allow them to remain there. Thus, because the determination of reasonableness is a question of fact, the trier of fact must determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that a foreseeable risk stemming from the owner’s mode of operation could occur and whether the owner exercised reasonable care in maintaining the premise in a safe condition commensurate with these foreseeable risks.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts negligence law, a defendant is liable where it owed a duty of care to the plaintiff, breached that duty, and the breach was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries, resulting in damages. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006); Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 742–43 (1995).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the elements of a negligence claim under Massachusetts law: duty, breach of that duty, causation, and damages. While the case cites a treatise rather than Davis v. Westwood Group for that proposition, the formulation of the negligence standard in Jupin matches the proposition’s statement of Massachusetts negligence law. Thus, citing Jupin for that general elements-of-negligence rule is accurate and supported by the text.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage.”

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts negligence law, a defendant is liable where it owed a duty of care to the plaintiff, breached that duty, and the breach was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries, resulting in damages. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006); Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 742–43 (1995).
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the basic elements of a Massachusetts negligence claim: a legal duty owed by the defendant, a breach of that duty, and proximate causation of the plaintiff’s injury. While Davis focuses on whether a duty existed on these specific facts (ultimately finding none), its statement of the general negligence standard aligns with the proposition cited alongside Jupin. Thus the case is properly cited as authority for the elements of negligence under Massachusetts law.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury. See O’Gorman v. Antonio Rubinaccio & Sons, 408 Mass. 758, 760 (1990); Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., 404 Mass. 624, 629 (1989).”

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 51–54 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: The duty of reasonable care includes the obligation to anticipate and guard against reasonably foreseeable conduct of third persons, including other customers, when such conduct creates a risk of harm to patrons. See Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 51–54 (1983); Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978).
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent focused entirely on proximate cause and foreseeability of the particular harm, not on defining the scope of a duty to protect patrons from reasonably foreseeable third-party conduct. The discussion of foreseeability is tied to whether the rape was within the foreseeable risk of specific security lapses (gate, refectory door), not a general principle that duty includes guarding against other customers' or third parties' conduct. The majority opinion in Mullins does recognize such a duty, but the quoted dissenting portion here does not support the proposition as stated.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiffs safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969). The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes.

Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..raw_text: Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978)
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..proposition: The duty of reasonable care includes the obligation to anticipate and guard against reasonably foreseeable conduct of third persons, including other customers, when such conduct creates a risk of harm to patrons. See Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 51–54 (1983); Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978).
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion directly applies general negligence principles to third‑party misconduct and holds that the original tortfeasor’s duty includes anticipating and guarding against reasonably foreseeable wrongful acts of third persons. The court rejects a narrow ‘keys in ignition’ exception and emphasizes that where unauthorized, intoxicated seamen could foreseeably misuse unsecured forklifts and harm visiting patrons, the defendant can be liable. This aligns with the proposition that reasonable care extends to foreseeable conduct of third persons that creates risks to patrons.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen….’ … Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable…. It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift… would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen… [and] that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area….”

Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s mild concussion and shoulder strain, as diagnosed in the ER following the incident. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935) (defining proximate cause); Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320 (2002).
Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1.support_reasoning: Wallace v. Ludwig does define and discuss proximate cause, but it does not apply that standard to the kind of factual scenario described in the proposition (a mild concussion and shoulder strain diagnosed in the ER, and whether defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing them). The case instead involves severe injuries, miscarriage, anemia, lowered vitality, and subsequent death from infection, and explains proximate cause in terms of a continuous, operative cause and chain of causation. It therefore supports a general definition of proximate cause, not the specific medical-causation conclusion asserted in the proposition.
Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The exception to the charge in the light of the medical testimony raises the question whether the injury which by reason of the negligence of the defendant came to the intestate could under the law have been found to be the proximate cause of her death. The proximate cause is that which in a continuous sequence, unbroken by any new cause, produces an event and without which the event would not have occurred. It may be assisted or accelerated by other incidental and ancillary matters, but, if it continues as an operative and potent factor, the chain of causation is not broken.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s mild concussion and shoulder strain, as diagnosed in the ER following the incident. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935) (defining proximate cause); Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320 (2002).
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: Kent discusses proximate cause in general terms and relies on Wallace v. Ludwig for the basic definition, but it does not involve or address any facts about a plaintiff’s mild concussion or shoulder strain, nor does it hold that a defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing such injuries. Instead, the case finds no proximate cause between the Commonwealth’s alleged negligence and the plaintiff’s injuries because of superseding causes. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority that a defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing ER‑diagnosed concussion and shoulder strain.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935). Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 867\u.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost earnings, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life. See, e.g., Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 867–69 (1991); doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776, 781–82 (1975).
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 867\u.support_reasoning: The opinion is a landlord-tenant and Chapter 93A case focused on emotional distress and warranty-of-habitability damages. It does not articulate a general tort rule that a plaintiff may recover all damages proximately caused by a defendant’s negligence, nor does it discuss traditional categories like medical expenses, lost earnings, or loss of enjoyment of life in the negligence context. The damages analysis here concerns emotional distress under Chapter 93A and diminution in rental value, so the case does not support the broad negligence damages proposition for which it is cited.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 867\u.relevant_excerpt:
On the G.L.c. 93A counterclaim, the judge found that Gonzalez had suffered two discrete injuries as a consequence of Haddad's unfair and deceptive trade practices: emotional distress, and the diminution in value of the apartment due to Haddad's breach of the warranty of habitability.

On the emotional distress counterclaim, the judge determined that Gonzalez had proved that Haddad's intentional and outrageous conduct had caused her to suffer severe emotional distress, and that such proof constituted a basis for recovery under c. 93A.

doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost earnings, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life. See, e.g., Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 867–69 (1991); doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776, 781–82 (1975).
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not articulate a general rule that a plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by the defendant’s negligence, nor does it list or discuss the categories of damages (medical expenses, lost earnings, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life) as a legal principle. The only discussion of damages appears in the context of reviewing whether a $440,000 verdict was excessive, describing the plaintiff’s injuries and consequences factually rather than setting out a doctrinal statement on recoverable elements of damage. Thus, doCanto is not proper authority for the broad damages proposition cited.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.relevant_excerpt: In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age (twenty-nine) and weekly earnings ($140) at the time of the accident; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand (her dominant hand); her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; her pain and suffering, particularly while her hand was in the machine and while she was in the hospital where her fingers were amputated and skin grafts undertaken; her disfigurement, including scars from skin graft operations; her future need for artificial hands; and her continuing discomfort and embarrassment.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: This action sounds in negligence under Massachusetts common law, as informed by G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence), and is consistent with the principles set forth in, inter alia:
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly establishes that Massachusetts slip-and-fall-on-ice cases are governed by common-law premises liability sounding in negligence and discusses general negligence principles, but it does not mention G.L. c. 231, § 85, nor does it explicitly tie the analysis to the comparative negligence statute. The case is therefore good authority for the negligence/common-law premises liability framing, but not specifically for the proposition that this action is informed by § 85. Any reference to § 85 would come only by general background assumption, not by express holding.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to “act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.” Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 169 (1980) ... If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property... the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.
